Topic.Title: Intel plans to crush ARM beyond 20 nm

Message.Msg: They are doing more than making promises, khitchd'uh. They already have 5 factories producing FinFET 22nm chips and are already producing some 14nm. ARM won't have 14nm FinFET for 4 years. It does raise a question, though. Why would anyone invest in ARM when it's clear that their fabrication is coasting to a stop at 20nm and they have nothing after that?

Topic.Title: Intel plans to crush ARM beyond 20 nm

Message.Msg: What would your report card say on Low Power IA? Still in process after all these years?

Topic.Title: Intel plans to crush ARM beyond 20 nm

Message.Msg: "Intel prides themselves on their engineering process. Yet, several years after declaring Low Power IA as the way of the future for low power computing, they're still making promises. Raises questions." I know you just can't wait ....but don't worry....Low power?... ARMs dealer like me will make a fortune while the ARMS buyers will experience declining margins.... and remember there is no switching back and forth among foundries ... Adding the equivalent capacity to start about 10,000 wafers per month costs about $1 billion, Anstice estimated. "I don't know too many people that freely make billion dollar decisions speculatively. It's a high-stakes, high-reward kind of play," he said.

Topic.Title: The Great Illusion

Message.Msg: Few factors here that need to be considered. 1. A year ago Intel had 0%, yes zero, share of the phone chip market. Intel is poised to enter and gain market share in the largest growth area for chips on the planet. A small share of the market is a hugh gain in sales for Intel. Some analyst are suggesting Intel has limited growth potential. At this stage Intel has more growth potential than say, all or most of the ARM camp. 2. Post PC era. Maybe in the developed world? Yet sales are steady there, and growing in developing countries. Maybe it is better phraised Post Desktop PC era. Mobility is the key to success, be it Notebook,Tablet, netbook, or phone. 3. Next big thing which seems to have limited Intels penetration to the Tablet market is Windows 8. MS's lack of touch screed support has been their biggest failure to date. Best feature of a Tablet that makes people buy it is the touch screen interface. Ie No mouse, keyboard to carry around. Hey, incorporate touch screen technology into a light weight compact notebook, or tablet, with the versatility to run your bussiness and productivity applications, would be, IMO, a better all round appealing product. The argument is that ARM is entering the market with Windows RT OS. MS wont even associate it's name with Win8, with almost No third party application support, and limited MS application support. Too little, to late, already done by google and apple. 4. Apple hype is exactly that...hype. The raving of apple tablet users about how great it is. Most people I know who have apple tablets are women. They like the form factor. Unfortunately in the WIN/X86 the only race that manufacturers seemed to be interested in was the one to make the lowest priced product. That lead to low cost, somewhat unreliable, poor driver products. Bingo, apple makes a fashionable,attractive, reliable, stable, product with limited perifials, with good driver support, charge high prices and win with the IN CROWD. The best product apple produces is their marketing campaign. Remember much of Apples success is due to their adoption of Intel CPU's in their desktop, notebook offerings. 5. Intel has huge manufacturing capability and leed in process, some years advanced to its competitors. Intel has huge R&D capability, my guess is that much emphasis has been put into the next generation mobile SOC. Intels Atom aging mobile offering, at this stage is offering comparable performance and power consumption to ARM's newer offerings. Remember, intels effeorts have basically been just a refinement of an existing design on an ageing 45nm process. Next level will be a complete new SOC, look out ARM, especially if this is released straight to the 22nm process node. 6. Remember that like the the so called post PC era, the commoditisation of the moble platform, be it Tablet, notebook, phone, generally has a 3 year life span. Don't believe me....how old is the device you are reading this on? 7. Intel is dominant in the Server, high end part of the market, cloud is booming. Lower power consumption is attractive forcing server farm upgrades. Is the ARM camp even close yet? yes they are experimenting. Though dont expect them to gain any great market share. All in all the

Message.Title: Note to FluMo
Message.Msg: Well, I can't even imagine why you would think that Intel has failed. Stop buying the swill that Wall Street is serving. This is a temporary dip deserving of maybe a buck reduction in price, two at the most. And yet now we are working on seven thanks to Wall Street manipulation and the momentum traders. The dip has been accentuated by the doom and gloom crowd who apparently won't be happy until both the US and world economies collapse. Well, that's not likely to happen but certainly they aren't helping things. If you hype doom and gloom enough, eventually it will happen. Intel has changed all of its priorities to address the mobile market. We have a bit of a lull while this approach gains traction but it is gaining traction. The Motorola Intel smartphone is evidence of this. The LTE roll-out in the US in 2013 will be further proof. Intel is nothing if not methodical in its approach. Intel tablets are now gaining traction. And notebook price points are excellent and an affordable alternative to limited function ARM tablets. The fundamental nature of what is going to happen will of course be determined by fabrication. And Intel is on the verge of a total fabrication win. We will see this in 2013. ARM is in trouble with their fabrication. There is no doubt of this. Because the effects haven't totally hit yet doesn't mean they won#$%$ inevitable. ARM has no answer to 14nm production. No answer. And Intel is already getting some production. Given that 14nm production is on the way, the idea that Intel is not going to be successful is ludicrous. The internet isn't going away. Data centers aren't going away. Big data isn't going away. The Internet of Things is just starting to roll out and it's going to be huge. Huge as in as big as the existing cell phone networks. Intel will benefit from all mobility on the server and data center side. And then benefit directly as smartphone and tablet sales increase. There is nothing in the Intel price for smartphones or tablets. Wall Street isn't just wrong. There screamingly wrong. We saw this when they thought Intel was worth 15. We're seeing it again now. These are not smart people, they are manipulative people - so don't let their temporary success get you freaked out. It's temporary. We'll see 40+ by the end of 2013. I'm extremely confident of this. We currently have a huge disconnect between valuation and performance. Intel would have to have a $6 billion dollar revenue miss to justify the current beat down price. So, we will get a big chunk of the downturn back on earnings when this becomes clear. The Wall Street smoke and mirrors act is coming to an end. In the meantime Intel is doing exactly what it needs to do. It's moving steadily towards 14nm production and total victory in the mobility wars.

Topic.Title: Note to FluMo

Message.Msg: I wouldn't get too excited about Apple either. They have an unmitigated disaster with their maps on the iPhone 5 and riots at their FoxConn plant. Headlines today on Fudzilla: Google Maps not coming to iPhone 5 Foxconn reopens rioting plant They are using 32nm on their iPhone 5 and have really no place to go. They are stuck between Samsung and TSMC with only inferior fabrication and technology at both. They continue to push existing products with little new on the horizon. It's not a story one can get excited about. Jobs is gone. He will be greatly missed. Intel on the other hand has a fabulous future. Don't underestimate that WiFi chip that is coming. It's a game changer. And Wall Street doesn't know any more about the Internet of Things than it does fabrication. The future that Wall Street can see doesn't go past this weekend. Mobility, fabrication, The Internet of Things, the WiFi chip all point to huge Intel success. If you build it, they will come. Intel is building it...

Message.Title: Classic Intel earnings warning
Message.Msg: As a fellow foolish commentator points out, the announcement is classic Intel. The company has a long history of waiting until a few weeks before its earnings announcement – the next one is scheduled for October 16 – and then lowering guidance. When actual earnings results are then reported in line with the original expectations, the company can declare the figures “an earnings beat” and watch shares rise by much more than the lowered guidance cost them. This is a classic game of Wall Street expectation management, and one at which Intel excels

Message.Title: Just A Thought
Message.Msg: With QE shots fired, the economic and political reality remain unchanged. The market looks unsettled in the near term. The quarter-end window dressing is likely to keep the downside limited. But the pullback in AAPL and selling on good new among the homebuilders yesterday suggests more profit taking is likely to be in the cards. The sideways consolidation during the past few sessions has worked off the short term overbought condition but the major indexes are still very overbought on the intermediate term basis. Technical conditions point to more consolidation/pullbacks. have a nice day.

Topic.Title: The Great Illusion

Message.Msg: There were a number of people that rose to senior management positions that needed to be pushed out. Fortunately many of those have left or will soon be leaving. I don't believe Paul O is among those however. Paul O. took Intel's helm after years of atrophy during the Barrett years in which billions were spent on a failed mobile strategy and AMD was allowed to take the performance crown from Intel and get a foothold with top tier PC OEMs. Problems of this magnitude can't be corrected overnight. While I have no difficulty being critical of Intel's management and strategies, and some are really warrant criticism, Paul O. probably deserves probably another 24 months to see if his leadership will deliver the products and results investors will love.

Message.Title: Motorola Razr i - Great All-Rounder Smartphone - Gets 4.5 Stars
Message.Msg: The Motorola Razr i is a great all-rounder smartphone. It offers a great combination of design and performance for a reasonable price. It's worth a look for its price and worthy of our recommended award. PCAdvisor(dot)co(dot)uk/reviews/mobile-phone/3400396/motorola-razr-i-review/?tab=verdictTab#top

Topic.Title: Motorola Razr i - Great All-Rounder Smartphone - Gets 4.5 Stars

Message.Msg: Motorola Razr i: Battery life We're still testing the Razr i for battery life in the lab but benchmarks aside, we found we got more than a day's use out of the smartphone with varied use. The battery lasted a solid two days before we needed to charge it up which is a good result for a phone with a large Super AMOLED screen.

Topic.Title: VOTERS RESPONSIBILITY IS TO VOTE FOR A PERSON WHO CAN LEAD US TO THE PROSPERITY.

Message.Msg: Aren't you supposed to call "them" the "job creators"? If you support any form of taxation or collective support of programs for the USA (military, roads, bridges, dams, ...), then you believe in taking from "those who earned their money". I bet you believe in "redistribution" too since those who don't earn money get benefits from those items. A big chunk of those who earn their money but do not pay federal taxes, do so because of tax credit laws put in place by Presidents in the 1970's and 80's. The new tax credits were initated pretty equally between both parties. Even Reagan with the Low-Income Housing Tax Credit. Businesses aren't hiring because they have no need to hire. Their current capacity and workers can support all their customers. The "job creators" have no need to create jobs if those who "don't work" have no salary to spend. You reach a point where you could give the "job creators" zero taxes and it would not create another job. Businesses aren't hiring because they can't find properly trained people. Businesses aren't hiring because Intel and automation has structurally changed the labor market and what part of manufacturing is left in the US has changed. Robots.

Message.Title: Intel smartphones(mini-computers) will have patented technology, LOT of it. Does ARMH even have 375 million dollars?
Message.Msg: Intel seems to have finally gotten serious about its mobile strategy. No longer willing to let ARM Holdings have its way, Intel is now looking to fight it out in the smartphone and tablet spaces that ARM has dominated for years. In June, Intel paid $375 million for 1,700 patents to "support Intel's strategic investments in the mobile segment." Translation: We're coming for your bread and butter, ARM.

Topic.Title: VOTERS RESPONSIBILITY IS TO VOTE FOR A PERSON WHO CAN LEAD US TO THE PROSPERITY.

Message.Msg: just touching on the issues you raised ..... I have never demonized anyone for being "smart". I also have never equated being "wealthy" with "being smart". There are many very smart people who are not wealthy (some by choice). Wealth is not a "smart meter". Is Paris Hilton smart? Maybe. I have no respect for those who lack good character and morals. (Note ... I am not pointing any general finger). Bernie Maddoff ? I believe that a woman has the right to decide. (GOOGLE: " freakonomics abortion ") I believe there is always an incentive and benefits to work hard. "Smart" is not the driving force there. There are lazy smart people. There are smart people who make unwise decisions and become poor. Education is good. Staying in school is great if you can afford it and have food and shelter. Having food and shelter is not always a given. There is probably some changes needed with the union structure but it is wrong to demonize them just because their goal should be to protect workers from abuse. GM? Were the unions to blame or the "smart" guys at the top who said "OK" to their demands? The taxpayer so far has made a profit on all their "trades". A large number of GM employees and feeder industries have been paying taxes they would not have if GM had went under. The GM story is not over yet. Raising taxes? Close some loopholes? Republicans have stated that their prime goal is to get rid of Obama. It appears that the will not let anything stand in their way ... including America or its citizens. They stand behind an oath to not raise taxes which makes your first suggestion a problem. They view closing loopholes as tax increases so that has the same problem. Obama would have a hard time since his opponents have taken an obstructionist position. Romney, I don't think really wants to do either but he will have similar problems. You cannot get a bill considered in the Senate without 2/3 vote because there will be some Senator who will put a hold on the legislation because he/she does not agree. 60% of the US citizens are not extreme liberals nor extreme conservatives. The election system and district lines just pressure parties to the extremes.

Topic.Title: Classic Intel earnings warning

Message.Msg: You know the game to well. Load up on Oct calls. They are VERY VERY cheap. You can make 10-50X potential. If a stock is depressed going into earnings it will rise. If a stock is pumped weeks before earnings it will fall. Classic WS.

Message.Title: See interview with Ken Fisher
Message.Msg: Ken Fisher: Bull Market Is Halfway Done The bull run in the stock market has reached its half-life, and large-cap companies are the way to invest from here, CEO Ken Fisher of Fisher Investments told CNBC on Tuesday. “People are optimistic about their own lives, but they’re skeptical about everything else. Therefore, we’re going to move from that skepticism, eventually, to some form of optimism, or lack of skepticism, and that means people who haven’t been in the market will get in, will capitulate and put prices higher,” he said on “Fast Money.” Fisher noted a trend from large-cap stocks. “This year, we started the process where the very largest stocks started outperforming,” he said. “Usually that happens just about 40 to 60 percent of the way through the time of a bull market, so therefore I think we’re probably about halfway through the bull market and we have several years fully to run.” Fisher picked five large-cap stocks that he thought had room to run: Intel [INTC 22.535 -0.26 (-1.14%) ], PepsiCo [PEP 70.35 -0.35 (-0.5%) ], Sanofi [SNY 44.20 -0.16 (-0.36%) ], ExxonMobil [XOM 91.74 -0.14 (-0.15%) ] and BHP Billiton [BHP 68.06 -1.32 (-1.9%) ].

Topic.Title: See interview with Ken Fisher

Message.Msg: No one should buy and hold any semiconductor stock, they are deplorable as "investments", that said, they are fine for trading. one could buy INTC for the yield, short an equal dollar amount of the SMH. A nice hedge with the benefit of the yield. fwiw, INTC started it's slide from the 27's right as the SMH hit rsi 70, and peaked before the overall markets did. Sometimes, they bottom first, ie only a short term dip is seen as in the cards for the overall indexes, ie QQQ, SPY, DIA.
